content.description:
This is the most fun you can possibly have climbing a corner 1/2 carpeted in thick moss!

In all seriousness, the climb is pretty good, and the crack and holds are pretty clean. The mossy face on the left hardly be noticed or commented on beyond that it does not really affect the climb.

Start from the roadside/ground to the right of a bushy corner, traversing up and left into the corner above the shrubs at about 8 meters up. Protect and climb the surprisingly good corner to the top. A rising traverse left from the top of the corner will take you to the anchors as for '

Road Rash

'.

A 30m rap from this anchor will take you to the ground. Watch the ends of the rope carefully if you have any doubts about your true rope length.
content.protection: A set of cams to 3" with doubles from 1.5"-3". The D'Antonio guidebook suggests a rack to 2", but a yellow and blue Camalot are certainly not only useful but eliminate some otherwise choices between runouts or tricky gear. The rap requires a 60m rope or longer if done in 1 rap.
content.location:
The route ascends the obvious, right-facing, left-leaning corner that ascends from low to the large ledge over 100' up. The route '

Road Trip

' branches off from this about halfway on a bolted line.

content.description:
The crux is th slab moves above the arete. Cool climbing up a nice crack that leads to great face climbing on the arete and upper slab.

This is a great climb that will only get better with more ascents and cleaning.
content.protection:
Bring gear up to a gold Camalot, long runners and six quickdraws.

Rap from a two-bolt anchor.

BE CAREFUL...a 60-meter rope just makes it to the ground.
content.location: Start 25 feet from the road and climb up to the obvious mossy crack.

content.description:
The crux of this route is on the slab above the highest overhang.  My partner and I both thought it was easier than it is rated in D'Antonio's guide (where it is called "Tweaked"). We think it is an 11a, not a 12a.  We thought it was easier than

Road Kill

to the left, with which it shares an anchor.  This builds up your confidence after struggling on Roadrash which is supposedly easier.
content.location:
This route is to the right of

Road Kill

and is the furthest right bolted route on the rock.  There is a large boulder at the base to belay from.

content.description: This route is much harder than the 10b rating given in the D'Antonio book.  The crux is at the top near the last two bolts where there are no obvious holds.  My friend had to aid this section and so did I on top-rope.  If you want a challenge, this route will provide it.  I originally rated this according to the book, but due to Greg Hand's comment, mountain project administrators upped the rating from 10b to 12.  Don't be confused since the guide is wrong.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor.  It says 5 bolts in D'Antonio's guide.
content.location:
The first bolted route to the right of

Road Trip

.  It is mostly a slab.  There is a bolt anchor to descend.

content.description: The crux is at a hand crack midway up the wall.  You start by climbing a chimney at the bottom or the slab to its left.  The slab will have no protection.  You then reach a short hand crack which leads to a small ledge below a RP-sized crack.  You continue up a small corner to two small trees.  At the trees, you move right to a larger tree where you belay.  The last pitch is only 5.7 and is short.  You continue up a crack above the belay tree and move to trees on the right.  We slung a tree to rap from here.  The crux is challenging, and the route is fun.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a #3 Camalot.
content.location:
This climb is on the far left side of the wall.  It starts at a chimney which gets smaller at its top.  You can walk off to the far right or do a short rap to the anchors on

Road Trip

and then do another rap to the ground.

content.description:
This is the hardest and best line at the crag and a good climb for about any venue. The crux is powerful and technical both at once.

Climb up and left from a low point to reach the ledge and bolts down and right from the top of

The Hand

. Clip a few bolts on the balancy face to reach the roof. Clip another bolt, and then pull some opposition and compression moves to get into a thin finger slot left of the protruding block. Reach back right and oppose the lock with a good side-pull/undercling. Battle for balance again to get a foot up into a dish on the left, over the roof, then continue up very thin climbing past more bolts to the top of the crag.

It is probably best to do this route in crisp weather or at least not in the sun in heat, as some holds are pretty small and sloping.
content.protection: Bolts to a bolted anchor. Do a 100' rap to the ground.
content.location:
This route starts from the road climbing up and left on trad gear to reach a line of bolts just down and right of the top-anchor as for the route

The Hand

. The crux is pulling over and past a small roof along the way, using holds on both sides of the protruding block of rock.

content.description: The crux of this route is between the 2nd and 3rd bolt.  Both my friend and I thought it was easier than the 10b rating given in D'Antonio's book.  We thought it was about 5.9.  There is a hidden hold at the crux which eases one's passage.  You can place gear above the bolts, on easier terrain, if you wish.  It would be a long fall if you fell near the anchor having placed no gear.
content.protection: Four bolts to a two bolt anchor.  You can place a #1, and a 0.75 or 0.5 Camalot above the bolts if you want.
content.location:
This route is about in the middle of the rock to the right of

Motorcycle Diaries

and to the left of Magic Bus.  You can lower or rap from the anchor.  There is an overhang at the second bolt.
